title: Gay marriage, income, and green card?
question: My boyfriend is an American. He’s working full time, has $40k in student loan, bad credit (late rent and car repossessed), monthly payment on car. Is he eligible to sponsor me for a green card? I’m an out of status F1 student for over 4 years now. I’ve been in California for 9 years straight. I have a clean record.
question_tags: Immigration,Green cards,Employment-based green cards,US visas,Student visas,F-1 visa for students,International student employment,Immigrant status,Immigrants and student loans,Immigrants and credit cards,Bankruptcy,Tax lien,Credit,Debt,Lien,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt,Employment,Foreign and immigrant workers,Tax return,Same-sex marriage
answers: Congrats on your engagement. If you were to marry your U.S. citizen boyfriend, and you entered the U.S. legally with a student visa, then you are eligible to adjust status in the U.S. As for the affidavit of support, the USCIS will require the most recent tax return of your petitioner husband, along with evidence of current employment. If this demonstrated income is at least 125% of the poverty guideline for your household size, then that ends the inquiry. The USCIS and the I-864 does not require an evaluation of all debts of the petitioner, nor is one's credit history relevant. If your petitioner husband's income is not sufficient, then you can include a "joint sponsor" with your application. Again, the debt status or credit history of the joint sponsor will not be evaluated by USCIS.

I understand things a bit differently than Jeff on this one. You entered on an F1 visa and are out of status. In this situation, a provisional waiver should not be needed. As for the income issue, generally debts are not considered, except perhaps a tax lien based on court judgment. Also, there can be times when the sponsor's overall financial condition places doubt on his ability to maintain stable earnings. He likely will qualify based on what you wrote, but you should consult privately with a licensed U.S. immigration attorney. I've included a link below regarding income requirements.
